Graphical abstract MCF (mesostructured cellular foams) and NbMCF were used as supports for gold and silver. Bimetallic (Au–Ag) catalysts were prepared by metals loading (Au/Ag atomic ratio=0.5 and 2) on 3-aminopropyl-trimethoxysilane grafted supports and reduction by NaBH4 before calcination at 773K. The prepared samples were then activated in inert gas at 623K or reduced with hydrogen at 723K. The catalysts treated in these ways were fully characterized by XRD, TEM, UV–vis and XPS techniques. Au–Ag alloy was identified on the surface of AuAg–MCF and AuAg–NbMCF catalysts. The composition of Au–Ag alloy was found to be sensitive to the catalyst pretreatment conditions. The reduction of Au–Ag containing materials with NaBH4 led to the formation of alloy with low silver content. The Au–Ag alloy was enriched in silver partially by the activation in argon flow and to a substantial degree by the reduction with hydrogen. The conditions of catalysts treatment also determined the alloy particle size. Catalytic activity of Au–Ag catalysts was tested in the oxidation of methanol in the gas phase. The results showed that the presence of gold–silver alloy on MCF surface was responsible for high activity of the catalysts as a result of synergetic interactions between Au and Ag species. Niobium in MCF support influenced both the activity of the catalysts and the selectivity to formaldehyde. Keywords NbMCF MCF Au–Ag system Methanol oxidation Formaldehyde 1 Introduction The discovery 30 years ago that gold catalysts show high activity in the oxidative elimination of carbon monoxide and ethyne hydrochlorination, has opened the era of catalysis by gold. Today gold catalysts are used in many reactions such as oxidation of alcohols and aldehydes, epoxidation of propylene, hydrochlorination of ethyne, carbon–carbon bond formation, and so on [1,2]. The usefulness of Au-based nanomaterials for catalysis can be greatly enhanced by the addition of a second metal to gold. The attractiveness of bimetallic systems containing gold is attributed to their improved sintering resistance, enhanced activity, and more tunable selectivity [3]. Among different bimetallic nanoparticle catalysts (like AuPt, AuPd, AuAg, AuCu systems) developed in the last decade, Au–Ag modified catalysts have attracted a lot of interests for catalytic oxidation reactions. AuAg catalysts belong to the Au–BM catalysts (BM refers to base metals such as Ag, Cu, Ni, Co), where BM is much more prone to oxidation than gold and as a consequence acts as a promoter to provide reactive oxygen in a variety of gold catalyzed oxidation reactions [3]. Low-temperature CO oxidation has been the most intensively studied process catalysed by Au–Ag supported bimetallic catalysts [4–9]. Mou and co-workers [4,5] have been the first to report unexpectedly high activity of AuAg-MCM-41 in this reaction. The Au–Ag alloy system showed a strongly synergistic effect in high catalytic activity. It has been proposed that in this alloy system, Ag played a key role in the activation of oxygen and this capability of Ag was a key reason for enhanced activity. Recently, Au–Ag alloy nanoparticles supported on titania have been found to show excellent activity in methanol oxidation under UV irradiation with high selectivity to methyl formate which is an important intermediate in chemical industry (e.g. to produce formic acid, formamides, acetic acid, ethylene glycol) [10]. Methanol conversion above 90% and above 85% selectivity toward methyl formate have been obtained. The superior photocatalytic performance of Au–Ag/TiO2 has been related to the special structure of the catalyst and the electronic properties of the alloy. In our last paper [11] it has been documented that the bifunctionalized gold catalysts containing Nb and Zr are highly active in selective methanol oxidation in the temperature range 523–623K. The presence of gold significantly enhanced the activity, whereas the Nb and Zr additives influenced the selectivity of the catalysts toward formaldehyde. It has been explained that the interaction between gold and Nb or Zr in Au–NbMCF and Au–ZrMCF increases the selectivity to formaldehyde by weakening formaldehyde chemisorption in the neighborhood of gold or on the perimeter of Au particles and the support. The aim of this paper is to study the gold–silver catalysts supported on NbMCF mesostructured cellular foams. One can expect a strong synergistic effect between gold and silver and between the alloy active phase and Nb in the framework of MCF molecular sieve. The focus of this paper is on the effect of catalysts pretreatment (calcination vs temperature activation in argon flow or reduction with hydrogen) on Au–Ag alloy formation and composition as well as the effect of silver addition and alloy-Nb interaction on the activity and selectivity of catalysts in methanol oxidation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of MCF material MCF materials were prepared by a one-pot synthesis according to the reported method [12]. At first, Pluronic 123 (Poly(ethylene glycol)-block-Poly(propylene glycol)-block-Poly(ethylene glycol)-block) (8g, 1.4mmol) was dissolved in 300g of 0.7M HCl solution at 308–313K. Then 1,3,5‑trimethylbenzene (Aldrich) (12g, 99.84mmol) and NH4F (Aldrich) (0.0934g, 2.52mmol) were added upon vigorous stirring. Following 2h of stirring, TEOS (Fluka) (17.054g, 81.99mmol) was added. The final mixture was stirred at 308–313K for 24h and then transferred into a polypropylene bottle and heated at 373K under static conditions for 24h. The solid product was recovered by filtration, washed with distilled water and dried at room temperature. The template was removed from the as‑synthesized material by calcination at 773K for 8h under static conditions. For the preparation of NbMCF material, ammonium niobate (V) oxalate hydrate (C4H4NNbO9 — Aldrich) was also added to the gel while keeping the TEOS/Nb=64 constant (Si/Nb molar ratio=64 as assumed, the value was chosen to avoid the extra-framework octahedral Nb species formation on the surface of NbMCF, the amount of these species increases with decreasing Si/Nb ratio [13]). The source of Nb was added to the mixture 10min after TEOS introduction. The catalysts obtained were labeled as MCF and NbMCF. In order to establish niobium content in MCF, XRF technique was applied. 2.2 Functionalization of MCF and NbMCF with organosilane MCF and NbMCF materials were grafted with 3-aminopropyl-trimethoxysilane (APMS) (Aldrich) in order to functionalize the support before gold and silver modification. The grafting procedure was carried out as follows: 5g of the support powder were refluxed in a dry toluene solution (200ml) containing 12.5ml of APMS at 373K for 18h. The catalysts (NH2–MCF and NH2–NbMCF) were recovered by filtration followed by washing in dry toluene (200ml), water (100ml) and acetonitrile (20ml). The powder was dried in an oven at 353K. 2.3 Modification of NH2–MCF and NH2–NbMCF samples with gold and silver The functionalized NH2–MCF and NH2–NbMCF materials were stirred for 1h in aqueous solution of chloroauric acid (HAuCl4 ×4H2O – Johnson Matthey – UK–USA) (2wt.% of Au as assumed) (the modified procedure proposed by Mou et al. [6]). After filtration and washing the recovered solid was stirred with 40ml of 0.1M NaBH4 solution used for reduction of gold. After 20min, the solid was recovered by filtration and washed with water. For the preparation of Au–Ag catalysts, in the second step, silver was deposited on the Au-modified NH2–MCF and NH2–NbMCF using AgNO3 as the precursor (2 or 0.5wt.% of Ag as assumed) with the same procedure as that for Au deposition in the first step. The mono- and bimetallic samples were obtained after drying at 373K and calcination at 773K for 4h. The catalysts obtained were labeled as Au–MCF and Au–NbMCF, AuAg(0.5)–MCF and AuAg(0.5)–NbMCF, AuAg(2)–MCF and AuAg(2)–NbMCF. The numbers in brackets indicate the Au/Ag atomic ratio. 2.4 Catalysts characterization The materials prepared were characterized using XRD, N2 adsorption/desorption, TEM, UV–vis, XPS. 2.4.1 XRD The XRD patterns were obtained on a D8 Advance diffractometer (Bruker) using CuKα radiation (λ =0.154nm), with a step size of 0.05° in the 2θ =6−60° range. 2.4.2 N2 adsorption/desorption The N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were obtained at 77K using a Quantachrome Autosorb iQ apparatus. The samples were pre-treated in situ under vacuum at 573K. The surface area was calculated by the BET method, whereas the volume and the diameter of mesopores were estimated according to Broekhoff-de Boer method with the Frenkel-Halsey-Hill equation (BdB FHH) [14]. 2.4.3 UV–vis UV–vis spectra were recorded using a Varian-Cary 300 Scan UV–visible spectrophotometer. Powdered samples were placed in a cell equipped with a quartz window. The spectra were recorded in the range from 800 to 190nm. Spectralon was used as the reference material. 2.4.4 TEM For transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurements the powders were deposited on a grid covered with a holey carbon film and transferred to JEOL 2000 electron microscope operating at 80kV. 2.4.5 XPS X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on an Ultra-high vacuum photoelectron spectrometer based on Phoibos 150 NAP analyser (Specs, Germany). The analysis chamber was operated under vacuum with a pressure close to 5×10−9 mbar and the sample was irradiated with a monochromatic Al Kα (1486.6eV) radiation (15kV; 10mA). Binding energies were referenced to the C1s peak from the carbon surface deposit at 284.6eV. 2.5 Methanol oxidation The methanol oxidation reaction was performed in a fixed-bed flow reactor. A portion of 0.02g of the catalyst of the size fraction of 0.5< ⊘ <1mm was placed in the reactor. The samples were activated in argon flow (40cm3 min−1) at 623K for 2h (the rate of heating was 15Kmin−1). The reduction of catalysts was carried out using H2/Ar (10vol.%) as a reducing agent (flow rate=40cm3 min−1) at 723K for 1h. Then, temperature was decreased to that of the reaction. The reactant mixture of Ar/O2/MeOH (88/8/4mol%) was supplied at the rate of 40cm3 min−1. Methanol (POCH, Poland) was introduced to the flow reactor by bubbling argon gas through a glass saturator filled with methanol. The reactor effluent was analysed using two online gas chromatographs. One chromatograph, GC 8000 Top equipped with a capillary column of DB-1, operated at 313K with a FID detector was applied for analyses of organic compounds and the second one, GC containing Porapak Q and 5A molecular sieves columns for analyses of O2, CO2, CO, H2O and CH3OH, had a TCD detector. The columns in the second chromatograph with TCD were heated according to the following program: 5min at 358K, temperature increase to 408K (heating rate 5Kmin−1), 4min at 408K, cooling down to 358K (for the automatic injection on the column with 5A), 10min at 358K, heated to 408K (heating rate 10Kmin−1), 11min at 408K. Argon was applied as a carrier gas. The outlet stream line from the reactor to the gas chromatograph was heated at about 373K to avoid condensation of the reaction products. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Chemical composition of MCF and NbMCF samples modified with Au and Ag and the location and coordination of Nb Two series of gold–silver catalysts were prepared: (i) supported on MCF and (ii) NbMCF materials. In both series two different silver loadings were applied: 0.5 and 2wt.% in order to obtain the catalysts with atomic excess of gold (Au/Ag=2.2) or silver (Au/Ag=0.5), respectively. The assumed loading of gold was 2wt.% in all samples. Table 1 shows the real Au/Ag atomic ratio in all the catalysts studied. The atomic Au/Ag ratio in the final bimetallic MCF materials modified by grafting with organosilane (APTMS) is close to or equals the assumed value (ca. 2 or 0.5). It shows that the interaction of gold (in the form of AuCl4 − ions) with NH2 groups (in the form of NH3 + ions [6]) is effective for gold incorporation. The introduction of gold in the form of negatively charged metal particles (Au δ−) formed after reduction with NaBH4 allows the modification with cationic silver (Ag+) with very high efficiency [6]. The loading of Nb in NbMCF material, measured by XRF method, is 0.9wt.% (Si/Nb=155). The location of niobium introduced during the synthesis of MCF material (NbMCF) in the framework and at extra-framework positions can be explained by metal coordination studied using UV–vis technique. Tetrahedrally coordinated species can be detected at the framework positions, whereas the octahedral coordination can point to the extra-framework ones. The tetrahedrally coordinated Nb is characterized by a characteristic absorption bands in the UV–vis spectra at ca. 220 and 260nm [15,16]. The octahedrally coordinated Nb gives the band in the range at 310–350nm [7,15–17]. The UV–vis spectrum of catalysts supported on NbMCF shows two bands at ca 225 and 265nm (not present for silica MCF samples – Fig. 1 ) from niobium localized in the framework of MCF. The presence of two bands indicates that tetrahedrally coordinated niobium species are in different surroundings (different ligands). This diverse surroundings comes from the structure of MCF (windows and cells) and the possible non- uniform distribution of niobium. 3.2 Structure/texture of MCF materials The mesoporous character of MCF and NbMCF supports and catalysts after modification with metals was confirmed by the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of type IV (Figs. S1, S2– Supplementary data (SD)), which are characteristic of mesoporous materials [18]. Both pristine MCF materials show large surface areas and large pore sizes (Table 2 ) typical of mesostructured cellular foams [12]. The average pore size calculated from the adsorption branches gives the information about the size of MCF cells (ca. 37nm), whereas the value obtained from the desorption branches illustrates the sizes of the windows (ca. 14.5nm). Surface area significantly decreases for MCF and NbMCF samples modified with gold or gold and silver (Table 2). Simultaneously, a decrease in pore volumes and cells size is also observed. The decrease in these values suggests that silver and gold are located in the cells (not in the windows) and the pores are partially blocked as a result of metals incorporation into MCF and NbMCF. The cellular foams structure was identified for all MCF’s materials studied. TEM images indicate strutlike structure, typical of MCF’s [12]. TEM images of MCF and NbMCF samples (before and after modification with metals) are shown in Figs. S3 and S4 (SD). 3.3 Surface characterization – the state of Nb and noble metals and the effect of catalysts pretreatment on the Au–Ag alloy formation 3.3.1 XRD, UV–vis and XPS XRD patterns of MCF catalysts modified with gold and silver show the diffractions peaks at 2θ =38.2° and 44.2° (Fig. S5 (SD)). However, because Au and Ag have similar facial centered cubic (FCC) structures and lattice constants (0.408nm versus 0.409nm) it is not possible to distinguish gold–silver alloy from the monometallic Au and Ag particles, on the basis of XRD patterns [19,20]. The detected reflexions corresponded to the (111) and (200) lattice planes of Au, Ag or Au–Ag alloy. It has been proved in literature [19–23] that UV–vis spectroscopy is very useful for distinguishing two kinds of Au–Ag alloy nanoparticles. For the sample containing core–shell nanoparticles, two surface plasmon resonance (SPR) bands corresponding to the absorbance of separated metal clusters (at ca. 500nm for metallic Au and ca. 400nm for metallic Ag) are usually observed [19–21]. A physical mixture of monometallic Au and Ag nanoparticles shows the similar two absorption peaks due to the SPR of Au and Ag [22]. The mixed alloy nanoparticles have only one absorption peak, whose position is in the region between the absorption peaks characteristic of Au and Ag nanoparticles [21,23]. The UV–vis spectra of catalysts studied are presented in Fig. 1 and the positions of UV–vis bands are summarized in Table 3 . The spectra of monometallic Au–MCF and Au–NbMCF samples reduced with NaBH4 and then calcined show the characteristic ultraviolet–visible band at ca. 505nm (Table 3) typical of metallic gold [24]. The addition of silver leads to the blueshift of this band. The position of the band depends on the loading of silver and the blueshift increases with decreasing Au/Ag ratio. The UV–vis spectra of all AuAg-catalysts studied (Fig. 1) show only a single band indicating AuAg alloy formation (mixed alloy nanoparticles). The introduction of 0.5wt.% of silver (AuAg(2)–MCF and AuAg(2)–NbMCF) shifts the band to ca 500nm, whereas the introduction of 2wt.% of Ag causes a shift to 476 and 493nm for AuAg(0.5)–MCF and AuAg(0.5)–NbMCF, respectively. The small blueshift of SPR band suggests that the alloy is formed only to low extent. The higher loading of silver (Au/Ag=0.5) gives an alloy richer in silver. Moreover, the band at ca. 255nm (typical of silver cationic species – charge transfer 4d10 →4d95s1) suggests the presence of cationic Ag δ+ species or Ag n δ+ clusters [25,26] on the surface of catalysts. The presence of Ag δ+ cations together with metallic silver has been found earlier also for monometallic Ag-mesoporous sieves [27]. It is important to note that the presence of niobium in the structure of MCF makes the alloy formation more difficult. The band at 255nm in the spectra of Nb containing samples is hidden under the bands from niobium species. It is known that niobium located inside the mesoporous silica (like MCM-41 [28,29] or SBA-15) is present after dehydroxylation in two forms: Nb–O δ− and Nb δ+. The same can be suggested of calcined NbMCF. Silver cationic species are easily located near Nb–O δ− species and are stabilized in cationic form because of ionic interaction with negatively charged niobium-oxygen species. Activation under the inert atmosphere (argon) or reducing one (hydrogen) changes the state of silver leading to the reduction of silver species. To check the stability of Au–Ag alloy and to determine the metal state in the samples before testing their catalytic activity, the UV–vis measurements were performed after the activation of catalysts in the flow of inert gas (argon) at 623K. The results reveal that the formation of Au–Ag alloy in AuAg–MCF and AuAg–NbMCF samples is sensitive to the reducing conditions during activation in argon. Significant changes are visible in the spectra of these bimetallic catalysts (Fig. 1). The band characteristic of Au–Ag alloy is shifted to the lower value of wavelength for all Au–Ag samples studied. It indicates the enrichment of alloy in silver after temperature activation in argon flow. For the samples with low silver loading (Au/Ag=2) the SPR band appears at ca. 495nm. It demonstrates that the AuAg nanoparticles obtained are AuAg alloy with low and random distribution of Ag atoms. For the samples containing higher silver loading (Au/Ag=0.5) the position of the bands is more blueshifted and depends on the composition of the matrix – ca. 460nm for AuAg(0.5)–MCF and ca. 480nm for AuAg(0.5)–NbMCF. Again the presence of Nb makes the enrichment of alloy in silver more difficult. In the next step the catalysts were treated with hydrogen at 723K in order to observe the influence of reduction process on the properties of Au–Ag alloy on the surface of MCF materials. The results shown in Fig. 1 clearly indicate the effect of reduction treatment. Irrespective of the silver loading, a significant blueshift of SPR band is observed. For sample AuAg(2)–MCF, the band appears at ca. 470nm, whereas for sample AuAg(0.5)–MCF, at ca. 435nm. In the latter case, the shift of the band close to the region characteristic of Ag0 indicates that Au–Ag alloy is rich in metallic silver. Moreover, an important observation is that after the reduction with hydrogen, the presence of Nb in the support does not influence the composition of Au–Ag alloy. It means that the reducing atmosphere (hydrogen treatment at high temperature) is able to weaken the interaction between niobium–oxygen anionic species and cationic silver and makes the reduction of cationic silver effective. The larger blueshift of the SPR band after activation in argon and the H2 reduction than after calcination suggests that more silver atoms are alloyed with gold during these processes. The effect of reduction with hydrogen on alloy formation was observed also for AuAg–SiO2 materials [6]. Silver in the form of cationic species on the MCF surface after reduction with NaBH4 and calcination process is mostly reduced to metallic silver and the interdiffusion between Au and Ag atoms during reduction process leads to deeper alloying of gold and silver. To better understand the surface chemical composition and the electronic properties of Au and Ag and Au–Ag alloy in bimetallic MCF catalysts, XPS measurements were performed. XPS spectra provide the information regarding the chemical state of gold and silver species on the surface of MCF catalysts depending on the catalysts pretreatment (calcination vs reduction with hydrogen). XPS results shown in Table 3 clearly indicate that gold in the metallic state is present on the surface of Au–MCF and Au-NbMCF samples. The binding energies of Au 4f7/2 are 83.6 and 83.4eV, respectively. However, it is important to stress that the Au 4f7/2 peaks are shifted toward a lower binding energy than that of bulk Au0, which is reported to be at 84.0eV [30]. It indicates that the negatively charged gold particles (Au δ−) are present on the surface of monometallic catalysts. Such electronegative gold species have been attributed in our earlier work [11] to the presence of nucleophilic centers on the surface of MCF and NbMCF, which are able to donate electrons from the support to Au particles (Au δ−). The source of nucleophilicity can be the defect holes in silica of MCF and NbMCF types (Nb species located in silicate matrix generate defect holes able to adsorb oxygen). The silver species identified by XPS on the surface of Au–Ag modified MCF and NbMCF materials studied in this work are summarized in Table 3. In our earlier paper [27] it has been shown that calcined mesoporous silica modified with silver in the same way had an Ag3d5/2 BE of 367.9eV and Ag3d3/2 BE of 373.9eV. As reported in literature XPS peaks at 367.9–368.3eV and 373.9–374.3eV are typical of metallic Ag 3d5/2 and Ag 3d3/2, respectively [25,27,31,32]. AuAg(0.5)–MCF and AuAg(0.5)–NbMCF catalysts reduced with NaBH4 and then calcined exhibit Ag3d5/2 peak at 367.8eV. The XP spectra of these catalysts reduced with hydrogen exhibit the peak at 367.6eV (Fig. 2 for AuAg(0.5)–NbMCF-H2). Compared with the monometallic Ag-samples [27], the alloying of Ag with Au, as a result of reduction treatment with hydrogen, shifts the Ag3d BE to a lower value (from 367.9 to 367.6eV). The shift is even higher for the catalyst with lower content of silver (from 367.9 to 367.3eV for AuAg(2)–NbMCF–H2 catalyst – Fig. 2). The observed negative shift of Ag 3d5/2 peak in the spectra of hydrogen reduced bimetallic materials is in agreement with the results reported in literature [5,20,21]. It has been shown for AuAg–SBA-15 that alloying of Ag with Au made the binding energy of Ag3d5/2 shift to a lower value (367.4eV), implying that the silver species had a great tendency to lose electrons through alloying with gold [20]. These results indicate that there exists an interaction between Au and Ag atoms and Ag atoms transfer electrons toward Au atoms through alloying with gold and that reduction treatment plays an important role in the restructuring of the particles and redistributing the Au and Ag nanoparticles on the surface of the MCF catalyst. The restructuring of the particles leads to much higher alloy particles dispersion (TEM measurements described below). It can be proposed that after reduction of AuAg-catalysts with the reducing agent NaBH4, followed by calcination, part of Ag atoms reduced to metallic form forms alloy poor in silver with low Ag distribution. The presence of niobium in the structure of MCF makes the alloy formation more difficult. In the reducing conditions further reduction of silver occurs (the alloy is rich in silver) together with redistribution of Au and Ag. The uniform alloy structure is generated as a result of hydrogen treatment. XPS results clearly indicate that Nb in NbMCF support is fully in the pentavalent state (Table 3). The binding energy of Nb3d5/2 in NbMCF is higher (207.8eV) than that in the bulk Nb2O5 (207.1eV) [33] indicating the interaction of Nb5+ with Si and confirming the localisation of niobium in the framework of the molecular sieve. Interestingly, the modification of NbMCF with gold or gold and silver shifts BE of Nb toward lower energy (Table 3) resulting from the interaction of niobium with metals (mainly with silver) on the surface of mesoporous MCF material. This shift is the highest for bimetallic catalysts. 3.3.2 The metal particle sizes distribution – TEM measurements TEM measurements were performed to determine the metal particle sizes and size distributions of gold/Au–Ag alloy nanoparticles on the surface of MCF and NbMCF supports (Fig. S4 (SD)). The average diameters calculated by measuring the sizes of individual particles in TEM images are listed in Table 1. Figs. 3 and 4 show the images and particle size histograms of the catalysts studied. The results obtained clearly indicate that the particle size is determined by the chemical composition of the active phase (mono vs bimetallic), Au/Ag ratio and the conditions of catalysts treatment (calcination vs reduction with hydrogen). From among the catalysts supported on MCF and NbMCF, the smallest average metal particle sizes are noted for samples with Au/Ag ratio=2 (ca. 3.7nm). The analysis of the particle size distributions of mono-and bimetallic MCF materials shows that the introduction of 0.5wt.% of silver (Ag/Au=2) increases the number of metal particles with diameters in the range 2–3 and 4–5nm (these fractions increase from 22 to 47% and from 37 to 43%, respectively) and decreases the number of particles with the size above 6nm (this fraction decreases from 41 to 10%). It indicates the positive effect of Ag (at higher Au/Ag atomic ratio) on the decrease in metal nanoparticles size after calcination. A similar effect of silver has been observed earlier for AuAg–SiO2 catalysts with Au/Ag ratios=3 and 1 [6]. It has been explained that cationic silver species adsorbed preferentially on the negatively charged gold particle protect metal nanoparticles against aggregation during calcination due to a strong interaction with both gold particles and the support. In contrast, the introduction of 2wt.% of silver (Au/Ag=0.5) leads to a significant increase in the average metal particles size from 4.7nm for Au–MCF to 6.7nm on the surface of AuAg(0.5)–MCF. In this sample, the introduction of silver decreases the fraction of nanoparticles with the size between 2 and 3nm (from 22 to 8%) and increases the fraction of nanoparticles with the size between 4 and 5nm (from 37 to 61%). Moreover, the particles above 10nm are present (31%) indicating the agglomeration of metal particles. It indicates that aggregation of metal particles occurs during the calcinations process, and the higher loading of Ag favors the formation of bigger particles. Similar behavior was found earlier for AuAg–MCM-41 catalysts [5] for which an increase in metal particles size with increasing silver concentration was observed. A similar effect of silver loading on the size of metal nanoparticles is observed also for NbMCF supported catalysts. The introduction of 0.5wt.% of silver (Ag/Au=2) increases the number of metal particles with diameters in the range 2–3 (from 24 to 48%) and decreases the number of particles with the size above 4nm (from 78 to 54%). On the other hand, the introduction of 2wt.% of silver (Au/Ag=0.5) decreases the fraction of nanoparticles with the size between 4 and 5nm (from 58 to 18%) and increases the fraction of nanoparticles with the size above 6nm (from 18 to 63%). The particle size histograms of AuAg catalysts treated in the flow of hydrogen at 723K shown in Fig. 4, clearly indicates the positive influence of this type of treatment on the decrease of alloy particle size. On the surface of reduced catalysts the fraction of particles between 1 and 3nm dominates (67–84% depending on catalyst). The exception is AuAg(0.5)–NbMCF for which the fractions of crystallites between 1 and 3 and 4–5nm are almost equivalent (43 and 53%, respectively). The average alloy particle size on the surface of AuAg(0.5)–MCF, AuAg(2)–MCF and AuAg(2)–NbMCF catalysts after reduction is about 3nm, whereas on AuAg(0.5)–NbMCF the average size is higher – 3.8nm (Table 1). 3.4 Methanol oxidation with oxygen Catalytic activity of the samples prepared was tested in oxidation of methanol in the gas phase. This reaction can proceed selectively to various products depending on the nature of catalysts and the temperature of reaction [34–37] or totally to carbon dioxide. Formaldehyde, methyl formate (HCOOCH3) and methylal ((CH3O)2CH2) are the main products of the selective oxidation. Formaldehyde (FA) is nowadays the most desirable industrial product, because it is an important intermediate in the synthesis of many chemicals, as e.g. urea, 1,4-butanediol, trioxane or butynediol. Methyl formate is another important intermediate in chemical industry. It can be used to produce formic acid, formamides, acetic acid, ethylene glycol etc. The results of methanol oxidation on MCF and NbMCF catalysts studied within this work are presented in Tables 4 and 5 and Figs. 5 and 6 . The effects of Au–Ag alloy and Au/Ag atomic ratio, metal particle size and niobium in the matrix on the activity and selectivity of the catalysts are considered below. 3.4.1 Activity of catalysts 3.4.1.1 The effect of Au–Ag alloy composition For both types of catalysts, based on MCF and NbMCF supports, the effect of silver addition on the activity of catalysts in methanol oxidation at 473–523K is clearly visible (Tables 4 and 5). A significant increase in methanol conversion is noted for bimetallic AuAg-systems in comparison to monometallic one (Au–MCF and Au–NbMCF) as a result of synergetic interactions between Au and Ag species, indicated in the discussion of characterization results. The formation of gold–silver alloy (detected by UV–vis studies) rich in silver is responsible for the increase in activity of AuAg(0.5)–MCF materials (from 21 to 74% at 523K). However, the enhancement of activity is even higher (97% of MeOH conversion at 523K) for AuAg(2)–MCF sample, in which poor in Ag gold–silver alloy is formed. It indicates that too high amount of silver in the alloy decreases catalytic activity. To confirm the role of alloy composition in MeOH oxidation, the activities of the selected catalysts were calculated in relation to the surface area of alloy crystallites which act as active components (the number of MeOH molecules that reacted per minute per nm2 of the surface area of alloy crystallites). The data shown in Fig. 5 concern the catalysts after reduction with hydrogen which leads to the enrichment of alloy in silver. The activity is significantly higher for the samples with low content of silver (Au/Ag=2) independently of the chemical composition of the support. 3.4.1.2 The effect of metal particle size The conversion of MeOH is higher when the size of metal particles is smaller. AuAg(2)–MCF containing much smaller alloy particles (3.6nm) than AuAg(0.5)–MCF (6.7nm) shows higher activity (Table 4). The reduction of AuAg(2)–MCF and AuAg(0.5)–MCF with hydrogen, which gives rise to the similar size of metal nanoparticles (ca. 3nm), leads to similar activity of both catalysts in the reaction performed at 423–523K (Table 4). It confirms that the size of alloy nanoparticles plays a crucial role in the activity of AuAg–MCF materials. Similar effect of alloy particles size on the increase in AuAg–NbMCF activity in MeOH oxidation is observed (77 and 88% of conversion for AuAg(0.5)–NbMCF with average particle size 6nm and AuAg(2)–NbMCF with average particle size 3.8nm, respectively). 3.4.1.3 The effect of niobium The effect of niobium in the structure of MCF on the enhancement of the MeOH conversion should also be considered. It was proved in the characterisation section that niobium (V) in MCF framework interacts with silver in alloy. Such interactions results in a decrease in Nbd5/2 BE indicating the electron transfer from silver to niobium species (XPS results – Table 3). The changes in electron density in the alloy caused by this interaction result in an increase in catalytic activity. Thus, as shown in Fig. 5 and Tables 4 and 5, the presence of Nb in the structure of MCF gives catalysts more active in MeOH oxidation. 3.4.2 Selectivity of catalysts The presence of Au–Ag alloy on the surface of MCF changes not only the activity, but also the selectivity. As shown in Tables 4 and 5 and Fig. 6, the selectivity strongly depends on the composition of Au–Ag alloy and chemical composition of the supports. 3.4.2.1 The effect of Au–Ag alloy composition The main reaction product which is formed in methanol oxidation at 473–523K on Au–MCF and AuAg(0.5)–MCF is methyl formate (MF). In addition to MF, formaldehyde (FM) and CO2 are formed. For AuAg(0.5)–MCF, the increase in the selectivity to methyl formate in comparison to Au–MCF, measured for a similar MeOH conversion, is observed (from 80 to 97%). It is accompanied by the decrease of FA selectivity. It means that formaldehyde is stronger chemisorbed on AuAg(0.5)–MCF than Au–MCF surface, allowing further reaction with the second methanol molecule toward MF. The reduction of cationic Ag species to metallic one and the enrichment of Au–Ag alloy in silver as a result of AuAg(0.5)–MCF treatment with hydrogen (UV–vis results – Fig. 1) causes further transformation of MF to CO2 (Table 4, Fig. 6A). 100% selectivity to CO2 in MeOH oxidation at 423–523K is observed for AuAg(0.5)–MCF–H2. Taking into account that the total oxidation to CO2 is characteristic of monometallic Ag-containing mesoporous molecular sieves [27], high loading of silver in alloy plays a crucial role in the total oxidation of methanol. In contrast, the presence of AuAg alloy poor in silver on the surface of AuAg(2)–MCF leads to a significant decrease in the selectivity to CO2 and to an increase in the selectivity to MF (66% of selectivity on AuAg(2)–MCF for 97% of conversion) – Fig. 6A. Formaldehyde appears in the products of MeOH oxidation when catalysts with lower loading of silver are used (AuAg(2)–MCF, Au/Ag=2). It has been shown in the literature [38] that the use of silver–gold alloy catalyst (40–60 atomic% of gold) increases the selectivity and yield of formaldehyde in comparison to those of the commercial silver catalyst when the reaction of methanol oxidation is performed at 823–973K. The formaldehyde selectivity improvement obtained with gold–silver catalysts in methanol oxidation arises from two effects [38]: (1) the presence of gold decreases the rate of the undesirable oxidation of formaldehyde to carbon oxides relative to the rate of methanol oxidation to formaldehyde, which is especially important at high conversions of methanol when the concentration of formaldehyde in the gas-phase is high and the concentration of methanol is low, and (2) silver in Au–Ag alloy has been suggested to dissociate molecular oxygen, producing adsorbed atomic oxygen, which can then spill over to Au and initiate the catalytic cycle for selective oxidation. 3.4.2.2 The effect of niobium The results of methanol oxidation on AuAg–MCF catalysts described and discussed above indicate that the formation of Au–Ag alloy on the surface of MCF support gives the catalysts showing relatively low selectivity to formaldehyde (ca. 20% at 523K for the catalysts with Au/Ag=2). The introduction of Nb into the framework of MCF significantly increases the selectivity to formaldehyde for the catalysts containing Au–Ag alloy at relatively low temperature and at high MeOH conversion (Table 5). One can consider the double role of niobium for achievement of high FA selectivity. It has been evidenced [13,39] that niobium species located in the framework of silicate matrix generate defect holes able to adsorb oxygen from the gas phase. As these defects contain Nb δ+ Lewis acid sites the adsorbed oxygen exhibits nucleophilic character. The additional nucleophilic oxygen on the surface causes the abstraction of proton from the methoxy species and leads to FA formation. Similar effect of Nb on the formaldehyde selectivity has been observed earlier for monometallic Au–NbMCF [11] and it is also confirmed in this study (Tables 4 and 5). However, the great advantage of AuAg–NbMCF catalysts is their much higher activity (almost 100% at 473–523K) than that of monometallic gold catalyst. A significant amount of formaldehyde (ca. 30% selectivity at 473K, at 98% of MeOH conversion) is observed in the reaction products obtained over AuAg(2)–NbMCF–H2 and AuAg(0.5)–NbMCF–H2 catalysts. The increase in the reaction temperature leads to an increase in the selectivity to FA (ca. 45% at 523K, at 99% of MeOH conversion – Fig. 6B). It means that over these catalysts formaldehyde is much easier desorbed from the surface than over AuAg–MCF–H2. At this point the second role of niobium can be considered. The presence of Nb in the structure of MCF is responsible for high selectivity to FA because of the strong alloy-Nb interactions which weaken the formaldehyde chemisorption on the surface of AuAg–NbMCF. It results in a much easier desorption of HCHO to the gas phase. Interestingly, the FA selectivity does not depend on the chemical composition of the alloy (Au/Ag ratio) if NbMCF support is used. Simultaneously, relatively high selectivity to CO2 (in the range 40–47% at 523K) indicates that part of the formaldehyde in the gas phase or chemisorbed on the catalyst surface is oxidized to CO2. However, in spite of CO2 formation, a very important feature of Nb-containing sample is its significant selectivity to formaldehyde. In contrast to AuAg(2)–NbMCF–H2 sample, AuAg(2)–NbMCF catalyst is highly selective to MF (65% selectivity to MF at 523K – Fig. 6B), similarly as AuAg(2)–MCF. After activation in argon flow both catalysts contain alloy poor in silver. The alloy-Nb interaction is weak and therefore formaldehyde is strongly adsorbed on the surface of NbMCF catalyst that permits its interaction with the second MeOH molecule toward MF. 3.4.3 The stability of the bimetallic alloy in the reaction conditions – UV–vis study To investigate the possible changes on the catalyst surface after the reaction, UV–vis studies of the catalysts after methanol oxidation were performed (Fig. 1). For AuAg–MCF and AuAg–NbMCF samples reduced with hydrogen at 723K (irrespectively of Au/Ag ratio) before the methanol oxidation the position of the band characteristic of Au–Ag alloy in UV–vis spectra is almost unchanged after methanol oxidation, whereas for the samples activated in the argon flow at 623K the SPR band position shifts to lower wavelength indicating the enrichment of alloy in silver after reaction (Fig. 1). The largest blueshift in UV–vis spectrum after MeOH oxidation is observed for AuAg(0.5)–NbMCF. It confirms that formaldehyde, formed during the reaction and strongly chemisorbed on the surface, reduces cationic silver species and the alloy becomes rich in silver. Strengthening of Au–Ag alloy–Nb interaction leads to an increase in selectivity to formaldehyde. The results presented point out that the reduction of catalysts with hydrogen is necessary to obtain the sufficient stability of the bimetallic catalysts used in methanol oxidation performed at 423–523K. 3.4.4 The reaction pathway According to the mechanism of methanol oxidation proposed in literature, methanol oxidation involves the formation of chemisorbed methoxy groups at acidic sites [34,40,41] with participation of nucleophilic oxygen or redox centers [34,42]. Methoxy species adsorbed on the support are further transformed to formaldehyde (FA) resulting from the extraction of hydrogen [40,41]. The origin of nucleophilicity in mesoporous silicas can be the non-bridging oxygen hole centers, ≡Si [43,44], superoxide radical, ≡SiOO [43–45] (≡Si represents a silicon atom bonded to three oxygens in the network and a dot denotes an unpaired spin) or O2 chemisorbed on the defect holes. The latter are formed also as a result of niobium introduction to the framework of mesoporous silica. If FA is chemisorbed strongly enough at nucleophilic sites, it can interact with the next MeOH molecule and form methyl formate (MF). It is the case for the alloy containing catalysts based on MCF matrix. Au–Ag alloy–Nb interactions weaken the chemisorption of formaldehyde on NbMCF in comparison to its chemisorption on MCF support. According to the rake mechanism, the selectivity to the desired product depends on the relative rate of its desorption to the rate of the surface reaction. Weak FA chemisorption on AuAg–NbMCF causes much easier desorption of HCHO to the gas phase and prevents from the further reaction of chemisorbed FA with the MeOH molecule toward MF. The faster the desorption of FA the higher the selectivity to this product. Moreover, the higher ability to formaldehyde formation of AuAg–NbMCF than AuAg–MCF is most probably associated with the additional nucleophilic oxygen coming from NbO δ − species in the support [28] and the oxygen chemisorbed on defect holes generated on NbMCF support [46], both located in the neighbourhood of Au–Ag alloy particles. It was shown [47] for gold catalysts that only methoxy species adsorbed on the support in the direct neighbourhood of the Au nanoparticles can act as intermediates, depending on their surface mobility. As a result, no migration of activated oxygen and the methoxy species is necessary. The fact that the length of the perimeter of the alloy-support interface increases with decreasing size of gold particles [48] confirms that small metal particles favor the activity of catalysts in methanol oxidation. 4 Conclusions The reduction of Au–Ag containing materials with NaBH4 leads to the formation of alloy poor in silver (with low and random silver distribution). The Au–Ag alloy is enriched in silver partially by the activation in argon flow at 623K and to a substantial degree by the reduction with hydrogen at 723K. The alloy particle sizes depend on the Au/Ag atomic ratio and the treatment of the catalysts. The positive effect of Ag on the decrease of metal nanoparticles size after calcination was observed for the samples with higher Au/Ag atomic ratio (Au/Ag=2). A reduction in the flow of hydrogen leads to a decrease in the size of alloy particles irrespective of the Au/Ag ratio in the samples. As far as the catalytic activity is concerned, the excess of metallic Ag in alloy formed by the reduction with hydrogen leads to a total oxidation of methanol to CO2. Total oxidation is diminished by the presence of niobium in MCF support. Niobium species are responsible for selective oxidation of MeOH, whereas Au–Ag alloy mainly for the activity. Selective oxidation of methanol can be also reached by a decrease in the silver content in Au–Ag alloy loaded on silica MCF (without niobium). However, the products distribution is different depending on the chemical composition of the supports. The alloy poor in silver, loaded on MCF gives rise to high selectivity to methyl formate, whereas the alloy loaded on NbMCF (irrespective of Ag content and reduction conditions) directs the reaction toward formaldehyde production because Nb-alloy interaction weakens formaldehyde chemisorption. The role of alloy particle size should be also mentioned. Generally, the smaller the alloy particle size the greater the increase in activity, but the size of the alloy particle cannot be considered as the only feature responsible for activity. It has been shown in this paper that by the selecting the composition of the catalysts and the choice of their activation procedure (in argon or hydrogen atmosphere) one can obtain contacts active at relatively low temperature methanol oxidation and selective toward desired products (FA or MF). The stability of the catalysts during methanol oxidation is reached only if the samples are reduced in hydrogen flow before the reaction. coredata.dc:description: MCF (mesostructured cellular foams) and NbMCF were used as supports for gold and silver. Bimetallic (Au–Ag) catalysts were prepared by metals loading (Au/Ag atomic ratio=0.5 and 2) on 3-aminopropyl-trimethoxysilane grafted supports and reduction by NaBH4 before calcination at 773K. The prepared samples were then activated in inert gas at 623K or reduced with hydrogen at 723K. The catalysts treated in these ways were fully characterized by XRD, TEM, UV–vis and XPS techniques. Au–Ag alloy was identified on the surface of AuAg–MCF and AuAg–NbMCF catalysts. The composition of Au–Ag alloy was found to be sensitive to the catalyst pretreatment conditions. The reduction of Au–Ag containing materials with NaBH4 led to the formation of alloy with low silver content. The Au–Ag alloy was enriched in silver partially by the activation in argon flow and to a substantial degree by the reduction with hydrogen. The conditions of catalysts treatment also determined the alloy particle size. Catalytic activity of Au–Ag catalysts was tested in the oxidation of methanol in the gas phase. The results showed that the presence of gold–silver alloy on MCF surface was responsible for high activity of the catalysts as a result of synergetic interactions between Au and Ag species. Niobium in MCF support influenced both the activity of the catalysts and the selectivity to formaldehyde.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of AuAg–MCF and AuAg–NbMCF catalysts pretreatment on the gold–silver alloy formation and the catalytic behavior in selective methanol oxidation with oxygen
